comments.commentBody: Confirmation of cabinet appointments requires the consent of the Senate. This is a safeguard to prevent ill-advised appointments. Senator McCain has every right to demand answers about Benghazi and Susan Rice's interviews. Senator Corker, a Senate moderate, evidently holds the same views. The President can proceed to nominate her and the hearings will further clarify her role. Afterwards the Senate will vote. The president won the election fair and square but that does not give him the right to avoid scrutiny of major appointments.
The majority of the population (or at least a substantial minority, including some very smart peope) still think this is the way that tax rates currently work.

You'd be amazed out how often I have to spell this out to people I'm debating on this issue. One thing I look to do to clarify things somewhat is to say that it's a tax increase on *income* over $250,000 a year, rather than on *people* making over $250,000 a  year. Now, both statements are true, but the first one is more specific and correct, and the second one could easily be taken to mean that it's a tax on that persons whole income, when it's not.

It's true that if tax rates cease to be marginal than the biggest losers (relative to where they are now) are those that make the exact dollar amount of income to be in that next bracket. That not rocket science though. I am not sure the way I would view it would be to gross up the rate on arbitrary period of income. That seems silly as its still the same rate. Anyway just keep the rates marginal not doing so would be way too "progressive".

Nice job on the election.

It should be quite the opposte. The 1% should object to having to pay 40% of the total tax paid and the top 10% should object to having to pay 90% of the total tax paid.

How is that equality?

As wrong as lobbying feels, I almost think it's justified wih that tax inequality there.
This should be the Apple mantra, "What would Steve do", repeat after me.....

That's a good start. A company as huge as Apple ought to be able to find the necessary talent to get this job done right.

I worry about Apple, now that Jobs is gone... Will they be as bold as they can be or will they decline into careful choices like they did in the 90's before he came back to save them?

I would call the Cyrus Cylinder a document--historical in the sense that it is an archeological artifact--but not 'art'.

Wikipedia defines the British Museum as being "dedicated to human history and culture." I'm not sure there is an equivalent museum of like stature in the United States except for perhaps some part of the Smithsonian.

It makes sense to me to show the artifact in major art museums here since that is probably the best way to make it available to the largest audience, although it isn't really 'art' in any meaningful sense.

Sorry, the BM is a much better custodian of this treasure than either Iraq or Iran.  After all, the idea that individuals should have freedom of worship is anathema to certain segments of Islam, and it could be easily destroyed like the Bamian Buddhas.

Is this art or history?  Does it really belong in London- or in either Iraq or Iran? For those who suggest the former, imagine if you had to cross the pond in order to view the Declaration of Independence.

My friends' 18-month-old daughter is currently undergoing intensive chemotherapy for a brain tumour. It is absolutely horrible, what the doctors are putting her through in an effort to save her life or tide her over until she is big enough to tolerate the more effective treatment, radiation, without "unacceptable" neurological damage. Across North America, 5-10% of children die of infections while undergoing this six-month chemo protocol. At our Children's Hospital, the mortality rate from infection is 0% because all of the children are kept in hospital for the duration. This is not done in many US hospitals because it is deemed too costly.

I trained as an EMT in the US but knew I could never practice there after my practicums with the local ambulance service and emergency room during which I regularly saw ability to pay elevated over medical need. I can't imagine being a pediatric oncologist, putting kids through hell, and then losing some of them to preventable infections because the hospital's bottom line takes precedence over their lives.

The findings of this study are purely correlational and not causal; even so, the findings are intriguing! There is a subset of Type I Diabetes referred to MODI (Mature Onset Diabetes I) and it would be interesting to know if low Vit D levels plus genetics are the trigger.

I am a MODI as well as several of my paternal relatives stretching back into the mid 1800's. They were Irish immigrants who settled in Canada and Minnesota.....northern areas where the sun, from October to March is too low in the sky to trigger Vit D production in the skin (its also too cold to expose much skin in the first place)!!!
Though that predictive correlation disappears in adoptive families--it's apparently not simply a case of role modeling but a genetic heightening of susceptibility.

Your point is so well-taken. Screens seem to be invading, and it seems obviously bad for us, but they're so new, society is entranced by them.

But some people really, honestly do need medicine to function, and it is a disservice to them when they are put down for it, just like we would never withhold medicine for a diabetic.
Worse yet, schools cut recess and PE, the only time the kids can move, then blame the kid for not being able to sit still.

ADHD is unfortunately highly over- and under- diagnosed and treated.

Calling it a deficit of attention hurts everyone, because it is more of a problem with focus. ADHD people put their attention onto all kinds of things, all at once, and skipping from thing to thing, and sometimes over-attend, losing everything else when they are in their chosen entertaining or passionate activity (anything from cartoons to chess to drawing to email...).

I get exactly as frustrated with people who want to medicate normal behavior (like a bouncy 6yo) as with people who withhold medication because "it's bad to medicate kids with this addictive drug." They don't realize that truly ADHD kids do not get addicted to their stimulant meds...if they did, it wouldn't be so hard to get them to take them! But as they are ADHD, it's no surprise, they forget to take the meds that help with their ability to focus on the right/important things.
Oh like the respect I am SURE you showed President Bush. Yeah right.

Read the book about Vitamin K2: D and K2 and A lead calcium from the bloodstream to bones and teeth. If any of them is deficient, the process not only does not happen, but the calcium deposits in the soft tissue (arteries) where it causes cardiac events. (Hence, D does lower cardiac risk, along with K2 and A, but these one-eyed wonder studies that 'science' people churn out can never see multi factor problems (which is why they have been wrong most the time about nutrition)).

Three different people have now told me about the The Today Show spot last weekend and your blog.  It seems that our daughter and you have been in similar places.  Our book about that time in our daughter's life was chronicled in what the WSJ called one of the ten best health related reads of 2008.  It was just converted to an e book so that others can have access to Dani's story. Dani, who was diagnosed with AML at age 26 recently celebrated her tenth year of being cancer free.   For more info see  It's Good to Know a Miracle, Dani's Story by Jay and Sue Shotel.
I just suspect Joie is more particular. . . and that is meant as a good thing.
Next time I see an airport smoking, I will suggest it look into getting a new control tower.

I had a hysterectomy/oophorectomy at age 39 because of an aggressive case of endometriosis. Estrogen supplements would defeat the purpose of the surgery and "nourish" the lesions caused by endometriosis, so those were used in very limited doses over a very short period of time because my hot flashes were particularly nasty (according to the surgeon, and she based her judgment of the severity of hot flashes by the way I dressed on bitter cold days).

It's 20 years later and my heart is as healthy as it ever was. I have MVP, which is common in women, and that's about the extent of my heart problems. I do keep baby aspirin in my purse in case I need it, but I haven't needed it so far. (I replace the aspirin from time to time since aspirin has a relatively short shelf life.)

I'll worry about a heart attack when my internist tells me I should worry. So far, she doesn't see any reason for concern, which is fine with me. (There is no history of cardiac problems on either side of my family, except for a couple of aunts who had rheumatic fever.) I tend not to worry much about health issues, now that endometriosis is no longer an issue. That was a continually annoying condition, but it didn't cause heart damage. I've had lupus for many years and it's caused severe joint damage; that limits my ability to exercise and some days walking is a challenge. I'm not going to worry about physical issues I can do nothing about.
Hahaha. Because they had better sense. Hahahaha!

In addition to the differences between men and women mentioned in the article, has anyone studied the physical difference in our arms? If I extend my arm in front of me "straight," it will not be the same as a man's arm doing the "same" thing. Our lower arms are connected to our elbows differently than men's lower arms are connected. I have no idea if this has an effect on overall arm strength or if it's simply an interesting difference with no noticable effect on strength or movement.

Historically, women had to do "indoor" things, often cooking with one hand and controlling a toddler or two with the other; if the cooking was over an open fire, controlling the little ones was very important. At the same time, men had to track and hunt food, often killing the animal with a long spear; earlier in our history, a group of men would surround the animal and hope enough spears caused fatal damage to the animal. Studies of pre-historic graves find men with the same kind of breaks in their arms and upper bodies as rodeo "clowns," who take a great many risks while the man who was riding the "bucking" bronco or bull gets behind the fence that controls the animals.

I've often wondered if women avoided getting close to an angry, violent animal because they were dealing with the babies, or if it was simply because they had better sense than the men of that tribe or village.

Obama won the election by a good margin - isn't it his prerogative to have his choices accepted, and confirmed? McCain has never gotten over losing in 2008 and seems pricked to do anything to stymie or stab Obama, even when he joins with the Fox News machinations of Roger Ailes to promote Benghazi as a major failure for Obama, suggesting that Obama lied. McCain has lost his reason - if he ever had any.

This from Wikipedia on Susan Rice:

"Rice acknowledged the many mistakes made at the time [of the Rawandan genocide] and felt that a debt needed repaying. The inability or failure of the Clinton administration to do anything about the genocide would inform her later views on possible military interventions. She would later say of the experience: "I swore to myself that if I ever faced such a crisis again, I would come down on the side of dramatic action, going down in flames if that was required."

Yeah, sure!

I've had excellent results using a neti pot to stop a sinus infection. Obviously, it needs to be thoroughly cleaned and fully air dried before being put away, but they work wonderfully.

Especially now that the FDA has replaced many of the effective steroid nasal sprays with some very weak and ineffective sprays, neti pots are a necessary method of relief for those of us with sinus allergies and the misery they cause. If your house is served by well water, it's probably a good idea to boil that water for 10-15 minutes before letting the water cool (covered) for use in your neti pot. Don't boil enough water to use your neti pot for a week, but boil just enough to use it once.
Irony?

I definitely think that dentists are over treating teeth. I'm lucky that I have an honest dentist gilbert az who after I was cavity free for over ten years, told me that I just need to come in once a year.

In New Zealand, we have married, heterosexual couples; civil-unioned gay couples; and "de facto" gay and straight couples.  It is quite common to use "partner" for all of the above, and it is generally understood in the relationship sense, not business.  But when I'm in the US, "partner" can have a somewhat more formal connotation.  Context can change everything.

“People like to do things that make them feel better, and they avoid things that make them feel worse,” he added. “The idea is for them to have the motivation to exercise again tomorrow.”

Well, Duh.
We should move this sentence to the top and then do away with the rest of the article.
